div.p: Greetings and best wishes. I give you and Belinchetto my greatest thanks for the little book of Bernardino; I have given it to be translated, so that I may see what is commented on in it and what needs to be done. I see that I singularly need the abundant and faithful help of God, who alone is sought by so many enemies; but I know the Lord will never fail me, to whom I commend myself entirely and I pray to Him to strengthen my powers a little more firmly; for I feel that the strength of both my mind and body is not a little failing. But let the will of the Lord be done.
Regarding the affairs of France and Calvin, I have nothing, except that he is gravely ill here; may the Lord restore him to us and console His church! Farewell.
Zurich, 24th of March, 1564. Yours, B[ullinger]. The consul was with us with his people; he said everything about the treaty.

We talked as friends for a long time; he hopes that the treaty will not proceed. I gave him letters of recommendation to Mr. Coignet and to Beza and Mr. Viret, who is now acting in Lyon; they have their friends at court, through whom the consul can be helped in his cause, which I requested from them.

The magistrate received him with six cups of wine; four from the senate dined with him; I also joined them. May the Lord bring him back healthy; he seems to be a good man withering, and he also said that I have changed much from myself; but this is how old age usually is. Again and again, farewell.
To the most excellent man, Mr. Johannes Fabricius, minister of the church of Chur, my esteemed and beloved lord and brother. Chur.
